article_title: Squire Patton Boggs announces leadership structure
article_text:
Squire Patton Boggs announces leadership structure - Chamber Hill inks two

With Adam Sneed

FIRST IN PI … SQUIRE PATTON BOGGS ANNOUNCES LEADERSHIP STRUCTURE: The law firm Squire Patton Boggs announced on Monday the organizational structure of the new firm’s lobbying and public policy department following the merger between Patton Boggs and Squire Sanders. The two firms merged in June and have been working to determine who would lead various practice areas. As previously reported, Sens. John Breaux and Trent Lott will jointly head up the overall public policy practice with Jeff Turner serving as managing partner. Under them, the firm announced a number of other leadership positions — lawyers who will manage teams built around defense, energy, financial services and tax, food and drug, health care, technology and transportation.

Story Continued Below

—Turner will head Squire Patton’s technology practice in addition to his overall responsibilities managing the day-to-day operations of the firm.

—Squire lobbyist Al Cardenas will be deputy leader of the public policy practice and will lead the firm’s Florida and Latin America practices.

—Former Patton Deputy Chairman Kevin O'Neill has a new role as deputy global managing partner for public policy, investigatory and regulatory solution — with a portfolio focused around global legal needs.

— Victoria Cram and Carolina Mederos will head up the transportation, infrastructure and local governments practice. Both were with Patton Boggs prior to the merger. —Former U.S. Secretary of Transportation Rodney Slater and Brian Starer will lead the transportation shipping and global logistics group. Slater came from the Patton side of the merger, while Starer was at Squire.

—Partner Micah Green — who formerly served as president and co-CEO of the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association — will lead the financial services and tax practice. He was previously with Patton.

—Former White House official and firm partner Robert Kapla will serve as the firm’s international policy practice leader, working with foreign governments. He was with Patton Boggs prior to the merger.

—Former Pentagon official and Patton attorney Jack Deschauer will serve as the leader of the Squire Patton defense practice.

— Josh Greene will manage the energy & natural resources public policy practice at Squire Patton Boggs. He came from the Patton Boggs side of the merger.

— Eugenia Pierson will lead the firm’s health policy work as head of the health care practice. She takes over amid turmoil in that department, following the en masse departure of former Patton lobbyist John Jonas and his health care practice group to rival Akin Gump.

—Finally, veteran attorney Stuart Pape will lead the food and drug practice, working to help clients with issues related to the Food and Drug Administration and the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The new leadership structure puts former Patton Boggs attorneys firmly in charge of the lobbying and public policy operations of the newly combined firm. Cardenas and Starer are the only Squire Sanders team leaders managing practice areas on the public policy side. On the other hand, Squire’s lobbying operation was small prior to the merger, and Patton Boggs has long been the top dog on K Street.

GOOD MONDAY AFTERNOON and welcome back to your regularly scheduled programming. PI hopes everyone’s Fourth was filled with burgers, beer, baseball and fireworks. Over the weekend, it was also the 25th anniversary of the debut of Seinfeld, which premiered July 5, 1989. The show about nothing would run until 1998. After that, Seinfeld’s four actors would struggle to keep their careers alive. After more than a decade, Julia Louis-Dreyfus finally scored big with “Veep,” and Jerry Seinfeld now has a popular Web series, “Comedians In Cars Getting Coffee,” as well as his stand-up work. Send lobbying news, gossip, tips and scoops to btau@politico.com. And keep up with PI on Twitter by following @ByronTau or @PoliticoPI.

** Why do Americans insure their pets and cell phones but not their most valuable asset? Income protection benefits provide peace of mind in the event of a disability, bridging the gap between personal savings and Social Security Disability Insurance benefits, and expenses ill or injured workers face. Learn more: bit.ly/protectingyourincomeunum **

HOGAN LOVELLS, SQUIRE PATTON BOGGS ANNOUNCE INTERNATIONAL MERGERS: Two big firms announced international acquisitions on Monday amid an increasing focus in the legal world on going global and providing clients with legal services in capitals and major cities around the world.

— Squire Patton Boggs has combined with Mamiya Law Offices, a five lawyer corporate and transactions firm based in Tokyo. That brings the firm’s total to nearly 40 lawyers in Tokyo and over 140 lawyers in the Asia Pacific region.

—Global law firm Hogan Lovells is bringing on 70 attorneys in a merger with Mexican law firm Barrera, Siqueiros y Torres Landa. BSTL has offices in Mexico City and Monterrey. The combination will be effective in August of 2014. In Mexico, Hogan Lovells brand itself as Hogan Lovells BSTL.

CHAMBER HILL INKS TWO: The American Academy of Family Physicians and the National Partnership for Women & Families have signed with Chamber Hill Strategies. The family physicians group, representing more than 115,000 physicians and medical students, is seeking work on issues related to graduate medical education. Chamber Hill partner Jennifer Bell said the new work shows that physicians are expanding their focus beyond the reforming the sustainable growth rate, though that’s still important to them. This is the group’s third active lobbying registration, according to Senate records. In the first quarter, it spent $50,000 with Polsinelli and nearly $630,000 in-house. The National Partnership of Women & Families is making its first hire since 2009, when it sought work on the Affordable Care Act. The group is now working on issues related to paid family and medical leave, hoping to advance the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, Bell said. The group hasn’t had help from an outside firm since 2010 and has posted no in-house lobbying activity since then, according to Senate records.

AT&T'S LOBBYING AGAINST MUNICIPAL BROADBAND: AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson wasn't sure last month if his company had ever lobbied against cities or states working to set up their own broadband networks — but as POLITICO’s Tony Romm and Alex Byers write this morning, it's clear his company and fellow telecoms, like Comcast and Time Warner Cable, have spent heavily against such efforts. "On their own, or as part of groups like the American Legislative Exchange Council, the companies have deployed their vast lobbying resources from the Carolinas to California, hoping to ensure that private networks don’t have to compete with government-facilitated alternatives," they write. The projects, which allow regions to put up the cost of building out networks for cable and Internet services, aren't universally opposed by telecom incumbents, but Romm and Byers take a look at the specifics in South Carolina, Indiana, California and elsewhere. All that spending, too, comes as the telecoms are pushing for a new round of media consolidation that could heighten their influence and reach. Read the rest, here: http://politico.pro/1mpP7TV

K STREET NUPTIALS: Via POLITICO’s Mike Allen: Jay Perron of the International Franchise Association and Anne Brady of Crossroad Strategies were married in Newport, Rhode Island, on Saturday afternoon. Spotted guests include: Todd Schulte of FWD.us and Lindsey Schulte of DWS PAC; Ashlee Morehouse of Oorbeek Morehouse Strategies and J eff Morehouse of Rep. Bill Flores (R-Texas); Ryan Triplette of Franklin Square Group; Brendan Belair (best man) of Rep. Doug Collins (R-Ga.); Mark Valente of Valente & Associates; Victoria Adams of Merck; Andrew Kovalcin of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce; Marissa Mitrovich of Verizon; Matt Haller of IFA and Rebecca Heslin of Gannett; and Ali Tulbah of McLarty Associates.

ELSEWHERE IN THE INFLUENCE WORLD:

BIG BUSINESS SHOWS LAWMAKERS THE LOCAL IMPACT OF EX-IM: Michael Crittenden writes on A1 of the WSJ: "Lawmakers at a recent House hearing on the future of the Export-Import Bank were given an extra piece of reading material: a personalized index card laying out exactly which companies in their districts benefit from the financing agency and how many people they employ. The cards, which supporters of the bank plan to give to every member of Congress in coming weeks, are part of a lobbying push by corporations such as Boeing Co. and General Electric Co., and business groups such as the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and National Association of Manufacturers. Their goal is to combat the most serious threat yet to the survival of the agency, which is under assault by new House leadership and conservative groups that say it amounts to corporate welfare." http://on.wsj.com/VSd7pv

SPEIER TARGETS LOBBYIST RELATIVES: Kent Cooper reports: “A bill recently introduced in Congress would require lobbyists to identify relatives who are senior government officials, and prohibit candidates and their committees from employing relatives. Rep. Jackie Speier, D-Calif., recently introduced H.R. 5011, that seeks to curtail the benefits involved with candidates who hire relatives and lobbyists who have lobbying contacts with their relatives who are government officials.” http://bit.ly/1n0ArGW

NEW JOINT FUNDRAISING COMMITTEES (Members of the JFC):

Arkansas Victory Fund 2014 (Cotton for Senate, Republican Party of Arkansas)

California Majority Fund (California Republican Party, NRCC)

Cantwell Wyden Victory Fund (Friends of Maria, Wyden for Senate)

NEW PAC REGISTRATIONS:

Alabama Liberty Fund (super PAC)

Concrete Reinforcing Steel Institute PAC (PAC)

NEW LOBBYING REGISTRATIONS: (Firm: Client)

None

NEW LOBBYING TERMINATIONS (Firm: Client (Type of Termination))

Crowell & Moring: City of Cleveland (Q2 Termination)

Crowell & Moring: Lancaster General Hospital (Q2 Termination)

Elinor Schwartaz: Lobel Novins and Lamont for California State Lands Commission

(Q2 Termination)

GovBiz Advantage: Livingston Group (for Anglo America) (Q2 Termination)

Moffett Group: Vornado/Charles E. Smith L.P. (Q2 Termination)

Natural Resource Results: National Forest Counties & Schools Coalition (Q2 Termination)

SENSE Incorporated: Nooksack Indian Tribal Council

(Q2 Termination)

** A message from the National Retail Federation: Retail is more than great products, the sound of a cash register, a storefront or a website. Across all states and districts, retail represents a lifetime of opportunities, from first jobs to lasting careers. That’s just one of the reasons why when retail thrives, communities thrive. And, whether or not you work in the industry, there’s no doubt that retail impacts everyone, everywhere, every single day. How well do you know retail? http://bit.ly/this_is_retail #thisisretail **
